string-array.name: arr_debate
string-array.item: GMF The Impact on Irish Agriculture
How Irish is your food: Agriculture in the West of Ireland

string-array.name: arr_talk
string-array.item: How to feed a family on a budget
How to run a community garden

string-array.name: arr_gmf
string-array.item: GMF The Impact on Irish Agriculture

string-array.name: arr_nutrition
string-array.item: Have we inflicted allergies upon ourselves, and how do we deal with them?\nThis debate will discuss the issue of how allergies have been caused and why they are becoming more prevalent in our society.\nThe debate will address whether we can prevent the spread of allergies, and how to deal with them.

string-array.name: arr_obesity
string-array.item: Our children are now 4 st heavier than in the 1970\'s: Should we as a nation be concerned about this? Is it our governments reponsibility to intervene? What are the contributing factors: education/food poverty?

string-array.name: arr_developing
string-array.item: What are the main causes of food poverty in the global environment? How does access to resources affect the distribution of food aid in stricken countries?\nWhat is the relationship of Global economic systems to food poverty?\nWhat can be done on a local level?

string-array.name: arr_tourism
string-array.item: Ella McSweeney, agriculture and food journalist

Why do people travel to Ireland? The people, the culture, and the Guinness?\nTourism figures point to a trend of walking, fishing, golfing, and cycling holidays. However no matter the purpose they must all eat, and meanwhile the Irish culinary world is making its mark with the best sourced and presented food.\nOur panel will look at the comodity of Irish food, and why we undersell ourselves when it comes to Irish food.

string-array.name: arr_agriculture
string-array.item: How Irish is your food: Agriculture in the West of Ireland

IFA, Professor Michael Cuddy NUIG, Teagasc, ICMSA, Kevin Sheridan\nWhat is the future for agriculture in Ireland?\nCan samll producers work together to create a viable and sustainable market for their products?

string-array.name: arr_fisheries
string-array.item:
What is the true cost of fish in a modern Ireland?
What impact will our fishing practices have on the future of the Irish fishing industry?
Why is there an ocean bursting with incredibly tasty fish that we will not eat because we have never heard them?
A debate on the current state of the fisheries, where it is going, and at what cost to customers, businesses and industry in Ireland.

string-array.name: talk_1
string-array.item: How to feed a family on a budget
A samll budget should never mean a compromise on quality and health. This talk will focus on feeding the family a wholesome and tasty weekly menu when on a budget.

string-array.name: talk_2
string-array.item: Every parent has to deal with it at some stage, and many of us have witnessed it at dinner parties. It is not easy to change the mindset of fussy eaters, but we can work around them. Come and check out ingenious ways to get the fussy eater to eat greens.

string-array.name: talk_3
string-array.item: How did the famine affect our ancestors? Come to the Galway museum to discover how the famine affected the towns people of Galway both rich and poor. From within the city walls, to the fishing village of the Claddagh.

string-array.name: talk_4
string-array.item: How as a city can we learn to be more sustainable, and provide for ourselves into the future, and what are we currently doing, if anything to ensure Galway is a sustainable city.

string-array.name: talk_5
string-array.item: The great port of Galway was once a bustling wine port, this talk will delve into the ports rich history in the wine trade, and reveal commodity long lost in the city.

string-array.name: talk_6
string-array.item: How to run a community garden
With a great increase in home grown and community gardens this talk will reveal everything to set up your very own community garden, when to pant, when to weed, and you need to get started.

string-array.name: taste_1
string-array.item: Sample a selection of smoked salmon from smokeries inthe West of Ireland matched with Irish Whiskeys

string-array.name: taste_2
string-array.item: A chance to meet and taste some of the unique honeys produced in the Burren and West of Ireland accompained by a glass of meade. Not to mention the delicious combination of honey and blue cheese.

string-array.name: taste_3
string-array.item: Come along and sample some of the finest cheeses from the West of Ireland, paired with beers, wine and local breads.

string-array.name: taste_4
string-array.item: A chance to taste some of Irelands few remanining fresh blood puddings and to meet their makers: Ed Hick (Co. Dublin), Jack McCarthy (Kanturk), and Seamus Kelly (Newport).

string-array.name: taste_5
string-array.item: The reassendence of craft brewing in Ireland will be on display, Here you will have a change to taste the new craft beers from Dungarvan, Belfast, Carlow, Cork, and of course our own Galway Hooker.

string-array.name: chil_1
string-array.item: The festival will feature a selection of children’s workshops and demonstrations over the weekend, with a focus on introducing children to the world of food in a practical hands on way. Bring your children to discover how honey is made, join in the bread making workshop, and make your own butter and jam.\n\nAnimals at the Museum. A Portable petting farm will be based outside the museum on Saturday and Sunday afternoon.

string-array.name: chil_2
string-array.item: The festival will feature a selection of children’s workshops and demonstrations over the weekend, with a focus on introducing children to the world of food in a practical hands on way. Bring your children to discover how honey is made, join in the bread making workshop, and make your own butter and jam.\nBread Making. Bake a spelt loaf with your children and introduce them to a healthy alternative to white bread while teaching them the skils of the baker. Expect flour fights, sticky fingers, and a fresh loaf to take home for tea.

string-array.name: chil_3
string-array.item: The festival will feature a selection of children’s workshops and demonstrations over the weekend, with a focus on introducing children to the world of food in a practical hands on way. Bring your children to discover how honey is made, join in the bread making workshop, and make your own butter and jam.\nHoney in the City Visit Doctor John\'s portable beehives to find out how bees make their honey.

string-array.name: chil_4
string-array.item: The festival will feature a selection of children’s workshops and demonstrations over the weekend, with a focus on introducing children to the world of food in a practical hands on way. Bring your children to discover how honey is made, join in the bread making workshop, and make your own butter and jam.\nJam making If your going to bake bread you need something to spread on it. Bring a bag of fresh or frozen fruit and transform it into a scrumptious sticky jam for your healthy loaf.\nButter making Learn to make butter from milk, and discover where your spread comes from.

string-array.name: other_1
string-array.item: Spanish Arch is the historical location of Galway\'s once thriving fish market. Sunday will see the area transformed once again into a local farmers harvest market. Market stalls will boast the best of the West local produce including: Vegetables, Meat, Fish, Bread.

string-array.name: other_2
string-array.item: On Friday and Saturday night there will be a host of stalls along Quay street selling a selection of fantastic local produce. Make your way through the heart of Galway and sample the city’s great atmosphere while tasting everything from smoked salmon and oysters to connemara smoked mountain lamb...beidh ocras orth..agus tart.

string-array.name: other_3
string-array.item: A reception in St. Nicholas Church on Saturday will honour one local food hero in recognition of their contribution to food and the Galway Community.

string-array.name: other_4
string-array.item: Cost - €50 pp\n\nArd Bia will host an dinner celebrating the diversity of Galway\'s Food Culture. Local Produce will feature in a menu specially designed for the festival.
